TITLE: U.S. Job Market Shifts to Lower Gear
SUMMARY: Employers added 142,000 jobs in August, fewer than economists had expected, and previous months were revised downward.

TITLE: For the Fed, a Sign That the Job Market Is Cooling but Not Cracking
SUMMARY: Fed officials are hurtling toward a rate cut this month, but Friday’s jobs data left their options open on the size of that reduction.

TITLE: Japan Tries to Reclaim Its Clout as a Global Tech Leader
SUMMARY: Japanese chip companies are tapping billions of dollars and collaborating with foreign firms as part of new government policies that look outward.

TITLE: 4 Big Airlines Face U.S. Inquiry Over Frequent Flier Programs
SUMMARY: The Transportation Department ordered American, Delta, Southwest and United to share more information about their rewards practices to ensure they are fair to consumers and rivals.

TITLE: Trump Calls for an Efficiency Commission, an Idea Pushed by Elon Musk
SUMMARY: Donald Trump, in a speech in New York, said the commission would conduct a sweeping audit of the federal government and recommend “drastic reforms” for cutting waste.

TITLE: Job Hunting Is a Challenge for Recent College Grads
SUMMARY: Unemployment is still low, but job seekers are competing for fewer openings, and hiring is sluggish. That’s a big turnaround from recent years.

TITLE: BLS Data on Jobs and Consumer Prices Faces a Test of Trust
SUMMARY: The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks prices and employment, faces scrutiny after several missteps. Some questions have gone unanswered.

TITLE: Why This Jobs Report Could Be the Most Pivotal One in Years
SUMMARY: It’s tough to overstate how much hinges on Friday’s employment update, from the path for interest rates to the economic outlook.

TITLE: Biden Expected to Block U.S. Steel Takeover by Nippon
SUMMARY: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is expected to raise national security concerns about selling the iconic steel producer to Japan’s Nippon Steel.

TITLE: Will Automation Replace Jobs? Port Workers May Strike Over It.
SUMMARY: A contract covering longshore workers on the East and Gulf Coasts will expire at the end of September, but talks have been stalled over the use of equipment that can function without human operators.

TITLE: Has the Spread of Tipping Reached Its Limit? Don’t Count on It.
SUMMARY: Both major presidential candidates propose exempting tips from taxes. That could encourage more reliance on tipping, and leave workers vulnerable.

TITLE: For Generations of Alaskans, a Livelihood Is Under Threat
SUMMARY: Something is broken in the economics of the state’s fishing industry and the communities that have long depended upon it. Can Washington come to the rescue?

TITLE: Gaza Debate Reopens Divisions Between Left-Wing Workers and Union Leaders
SUMMARY: Last week’s Democratic National Convention surfaced differences over the war in Gaza that could widen fissures between labor activists and union officials.

TITLE: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Stays Cool, Keeping a Rate Cut Imminent
SUMMARY: Inflation remained cool in July, based on the Personal Consumption Expenditures index, keeping the Federal Reserve on track for rate cuts.

TITLE: Harris and Trump Have Differing Plans to Solve Housing Crisis
SUMMARY: The two presidential nominees are talking about their approaches for solving America’s affordability crisis. But would their plans work?

TITLE: The Report Card on Guaranteed Income Is Still Incomplete
SUMMARY: A three-year analysis of unconditional cash stipends concluded that the initiative has had some success, but not the transformational impact its proponents hoped for.

TITLE: Why Interest Rate Cuts Won’t Fix a Global Housing Affordability Crisis
SUMMARY: Central bankers are lowering borrowing costs, but that won’t be a cure-all for a widespread lack of affordable housing.

TITLE: Where Does Biden’s Student Loan Debt Plan Stand? Here’s What to Know.
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court refused to allow a key part of President Biden’s student debt plan to move forward. Here’s what’s left of it, and who could still benefit.

TITLE: How Wall Street Learned About Last Week’s Labor Data Before the Public
SUMMARY: The Labor Department provided insight into a recent lapse in which revised payroll data was given out à la carte before it went online.

TITLE: Harris and Trump Embrace Tariffs
SUMMARY: Both Democrats and Republicans are expressing support for tariffs to protect American industry, reversing decades of trade thinking in Washington.
